summary: This document is a chain of emails from January 2020 between federal prosecutors and attorney Teri Gibbs regarding potential witnesses in the Ghislaine Maxwell investigation. It discusses a former assistant to Maxwell who alleges sexual assault by Jeffrey Epstein and witnessing Maxwell's relationship with Epstein, and another client who witnessed Prince Andrew's interactions with an unnamed individual.

persons.name: Teri Gibbs
persons.context: Attorney who initiates contact with federal prosecutors to offer information from her clients, one a former assistant to Ghislaine Maxwell and another a witness to Prince Andrew's interactions.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Referred to as 'GM'. Described as the employer of a witness from 2003-2007, who allegedly instructed the witness to go to Jeffrey Epstein's residence where she was assaulted.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Referred to as 'JE'. Allegedly paid the witness through his corporation and was the perpetrator of sexual assaults on the witness at his residence.

persons.name: Prince Andrew
persons.context: Mentioned as an individual whose interactions were witnessed by another client of attorney Teri Gibbs.

persons.name: Colleen Mullen
persons.context: CC'd on several emails in the chain, appears to be part of the prosecutorial team receiving the witness information.

persons.name: Lisa Bloom
persons.context: Mentioned as being available with Teri Gibbs for a conference regarding a witness.

connections.description: The witness is described as being a witness to the relationship between JE and GM. Maxwell allegedly instructed the witness to go to Epstein's residence.
The witness was an assistant to Maxwell approximately 2003-2007 and functionally worked for both Maxwell and Epstein.
Epstein allegedly assaulted the witness on at least three occasions when she was instructed to go to his residence. He paid her through his corporation.
Gibbs is communicating with Mullen, a federal prosecutor, to provide witness information and schedule interviews.
Gibbs states she and Attorney Lisa Bloom are available for a conference regarding a witness.

events.title: Witness's employment and assaults
events.description: A witness was employed as an assistant to Ghislaine Maxwell. During this time, on at least three occasions, Maxwell instructed her to go to Jeffrey Epstein's residence where she was sexually assaulted by Epstein.

events.title: Prosecutor's internal assessment of witness
events.description: A federal prosecutor emails colleagues stating their view that if they can charge Ghislaine Maxwell without interviewing this particular witness first, she would be a good candidate for a post-charge conversation.

events.title: Scheduling call between attorney and prosecutors
events.description: Attorney Teri Gibbs and federal prosecutors schedule a call for January 23, 2020, to discuss information from her clients.

events.title: Initial contact regarding Prince Andrew witness
events.description: Attorney Teri Gibbs first contacts federal prosecutors to inform them she has a client who witnessed Prince Andrew's interactions with an unnamed individual.

keyFacts: A former assistant to Ghislaine Maxwell (2003-2007) alleges she was sexually assaulted by Jeffrey Epstein on at least three occasions after being instructed by Maxwell to go to Epstein's residence.
On two of the assault occasions, other women were present and the witness was instructed to engage in sexual acts with them; one was named but redacted, the other's name was not remembered.
The witness was over 18 during the alleged assaults and was paid by Epstein through his corporation, making her a potential witness to the Epstein-Maxwell relationship.
Attorney Teri Gibbs also represents another client who witnessed interactions involving Prince Andrew, indicating separate lines of inquiry for investigators.
Federal prosecutors internally debated the timing of interviewing the Maxwell assistant, considering a post-charge interview if they could charge Maxwell without her testimony first.
